{{Infobox person | name = Adam Scott | image = Adam Scott by Gage Skidmore.jpg | caption = Scott at the 2015 [[San Diego Comic Con]] |birth_name=Adam Paul Scott | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1973|4|3}} | birth_place = [[Santa Cruz, California]], U.S. | occupation = Actor, [[Film director|director]], [[screenwriter]], producer, comedian | yearsactive = 1994–present | spouse = {{marriage|Naomi Sablan|2005}} | children = 2 }} '''Adam Paul Scott''' (born April 3, 1973) is an American actor, comedian, producer, and podcaster. He is known for his role as [[Ben Wyatt (Parks and Recreation)|Ben Wyatt]] in the NBC sitcom ''[[Parks and Recreation]]''. He has also appeared as Derek in the film ''[[Step Brothers (film)|Step Brothers]]'', Henry Pollard in the [[Starz]] sitcom ''[[Party Down]]'', and Ed Mackenzie in the [[HBO]] series ''[[Big Little Lies (TV series)|Big Little Lies]]''. == Early life == Scott was born in [[Santa Cruz, California]],{{cite web|url=http://search.ancestry.com/cgi-bin/sse.dll?rank=1&new=1&gsfn=adam+p&gsln=scott&msbdy=1973&dnyref=1&gss=angs-c&pcat=BMD_BIRTH&h=12628265&recoff=7+8+9&db=cabirth1905&indiv=1&ml_rpos=1|title=California Birth Index, 1905-1995, Ancestry.com|work=ancestry.com|accessdate=14 February 2015}} to Anne (née Quartararo) and Dougald Scott,{{cite web|url=http://www.tvguide.com/celebrities/adam-scott/bio/138177|title=Adam Scott|work=TVGuide.com|accessdate=14 February 2015}} both of whom are retired teachers.{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/life/people/2008-07-22-adam-scott_N.htm|title=When somebody needs a brother, here's Adam Scott|last=Keck|first=William|date=2008-07-22|website=USA Today|publisher=|accessdate=2011-03-02}}{{Cite web|url=http://video.gq.com/watch/adam-scott-goes-undercover-on-reddit-instagram-and-twitter|title=Adam Scott Goes Undercover on Reddit, Instagram, and Twitter|website=GQ Videos|language=en|access-date=2018-04-07}} He is of one quarter [[Sicilian Americans|Sicilian]] descent, on his mother’s side.{{cite web|url=http://www.bonappetit.com/columns/my-morning-routine/article/adam-scott-mmr|title=Adam Scott Parties Down With Quinoa, Eats a Pan of Rice Krispie Treats|work=bonappetit.com|accessdate=1 January 2017}} He has two older siblings, Shannon and David. He graduated from [[Harbor High School (California)|Harbor High School]]{{cite web|url=http://www.harboralumni.com/News.html |title=Harbor Alumni Hall of Achievement |date=2011-02-26 |accessdate=2014-01-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140115025016/http://www.harboralumni.com/News.html |archivedate=2014-01-15 }} and the [[American Academy of Dramatic Arts]] in [[Los Angeles, California]].{{cite web|url=http://www.aada.org/alumni/alumni_news_200911.html |title=American Academy of Dramatic Arts Alumni News |publisher=Aada.org |date= |accessdate=2012-01-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120213222118/http://www.aada.org/alumni/alumni_news_200911.html |archivedate=2012-02-13 }} ==Career== === Film === [[File:AdamScottTIFFSept2011.jpg|right|thumb|upright|Adam Scott at the 2012 Toronto Film Festival]] Scott has appeared in several feature films, including ''[[Hellraiser: Bloodline]]'' (1996), ''[[Star Trek: First Contact]]'' (1996), ''[[The Lesser Evil (1998 film)|The Lesser Evil]]'' (1998), ''[[High Crimes]]'' (2002), ''[[The Aviator (2004 film)|The Aviator]]'' (2004), ''[[Torque (film)|Torque]]'' (2004), ''[[Monster-in-Law]]'' (2005), ''[[Who Loves the Sun]]'' (2006), ''[[Knocked Up]]'' (2007), ''[[Step Brothers (film)|Step Brothers]]'' (2008), ''[[August (2008 film)|August]]'' (2008), ''[[Piranha 3D]]'' (2010),{{cite web|url=http://www.dreadcentral.com/news/37106/adam-scott-talks-piranha-3d-its-all-about-boobs-and-blood-hallelujah |title=Adam Scott Talks Piranha 3D - It's All About Boobs and Blood! Hallelujah! |publisher=Dreadcentral.com |date= |accessdate=2012-01-16}} and ''[[Leap Year (2010 film)|Leap Year]]'' (2010). Scott's name appears next to [[Jon Hamm]]'s name in the film ''[[Anchorman: The Legend of Ron Burgundy|Anchorman]]'' in one of the broadcast's credits. In an appearance on G4's ''[[Attack of the Show!]]'' program on April 21, 2011, he confirmed that this was due to his and Hamm's friendship with producer [[Shauna Robertson]], who put their names in the credits as an Easter egg. He played Ted Hendricks, Walter Mitty's detestable corporate boss, in the 2013 remake of ''[[The Secret Life of Walter Mitty (2013 film)|The Secret Life of Walter Mitty]]''. Scott appeared in the films ''[[Our Idiot Brother]]'' (2011) as Jeremy{{cite web|url=http://social.entertainment.msn.com/movies/blogs/the-hitlist-blogpost.aspx?post=76f21cd8-028f-4139-a58f-c48a793c5c56|title=Adam Scott and 'Our Idiot Brother'|last=|first=|date=|website=MSN|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120319011439/http://social.entertainment.msn.com/movies/blogs/the-hitlist-blogpost.aspx?post=76f21cd8-028f-4139-a58f-c48a793c5c56|archive-date=2012-03-19|dead-url=yes|access-date=|df=}} and ''[[Bachelorette (film)|Bachelorette]]''. He also starred as Jason Fryman in ''[[Friends with Kids]]'' (2012). He starred as Caleb Sinclaire in the 2010 film ''[[The Vicious Kind]]'', a more dramatic role than his previous comedic endeavors, for which Scott was nominated for an Independent Spirit Award for best actor. The film itself received positive reviews, and he won two individual awards at two separate film festivals. He starred in the film ''Passenger Side'', released on DVD on October 26, 2010.{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/dp/B003W2XOU6|title=Passenger Side on Amazon.com|last=|first=|date=|website=Amazon|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101028160610/https://www.amazon.com/dp/B003W2XOU6|archive-date=2010-10-28|dead-url=yes|access-date=}} Scott's film ''[[A.C.O.D.]]'' premiered at the 2013 Sundance Film Festival.{{cite web|url=http://inthemixxshow.com/2870/fall-season-2013-episode-3-3|title=Fall Season 2013: Episode 3 - In the Mixx|work=In the Mixx|accessdate=14 February 2015}} In 2015, he worked as executive producer on, and portrayed Alex in, the comedy film ''[[The Overnight]]'',{{cite web|url=http://www.thewrap.com/adam-scott-david-koechner-join-legendarys-horror-comedy-krampus-exclusive/|title=Adam Scott, David Koechner Join Legendary’s Horror Comedy ‘Krampus’ (Exclusive)|last=Sneider|first=Jeff|date=March 3, 2015|website=The Wrap|access-date=October 18, 2017}} and also co-starred in the Christmas comedy slasher film ''[[Krampus (film)|Krampus]]''.{{Cite news|url=http://www.dreadcentral.com/news/91861/krampus-naughty-new-victims-join-cast/|title=Krampus - Naughty New Victims Join the Cast|last=|first=|date=March 3, 2015|work=Dread Central|access-date=October 18, 2017|language=en-US}} === Television === On television, he appeared as Griff Hawkins in the series ''[[Boy Meets World]]'' and Josh on ''[[Party of Five]]'', as well as [[David Fisher (Six Feet Under)|David]]'s love interest, Ben Cooper, on ''[[Six Feet Under (TV series)|Six Feet Under]]''. He played Palek on the HBO drama ''[[Tell Me You Love Me (TV series)|Tell Me You Love Me]]'' (2007). Scott played a [[cocaine]]-addicted, delirious baseball front office representative in the first and second seasons of the [[HBO]] series ''[[Eastbound & Down]]''. From 2009 to 2010, he appeared on the [[Starz (TV channel)|Starz]] network show ''[[Party Down]]''. His role in ''Party Down'' earned him an ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' [[Ewwy Award|Ewwy]] nomination for Best Actor in a Comedy Series in 2009.{{cite web|url=http://whosnews.usaweekend.com/2010/04/adam-scott-lives-it-up-on-party-down/|title=Adam Scott lives it up on ‘Party Down’|last=|first=|date=2010-04-21|website=|publisher=whosnews.usaweekend.com|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130205062354/http://whosnews.usaweekend.com/2010/04/adam-scott-lives-it-up-on-party-down/|archive-date=2013-02-05|dead-url=yes|accessdate=2012-01-16|df=}} In 2010, Scott joined the cast of [[NBC]]'s acclaimed comedy series ''[[Parks and Recreation]]'', in which he played [[Ben Wyatt (Parks and Recreation)|Ben Wyatt]], a [[state auditor]] who arrives in the fictional town of [[Pawnee (Parks and Recreation)|Pawnee, Indiana]] to evaluate the town's funds.{{cite news |last=Sepinwall |first=Alan |date=2010-03-05 |title='Parks and Recreation' lands 'Party Down' star Adam Scott |work=[[The Star Ledger]]}} He appeared as a guest star along with [[Rob Lowe]] in the [[Parks and Recreation (season 2)|second season]] before becoming a main character for the remainder of the series. The show's [[Parks and Recreation (season 7)|seventh and final season]] concluded in February 2015. Scott has appeared in the [[Adult Swim]] comedy ''[[Childrens Hospital]]''. He was also on the show ''[[NTSF:SD:SUV::]]'', in the episode "The Risky Business of Being Alone in Your Home", and the annual Adult Swim special ''[[The Greatest Event in Television History]]'', which he also created and produced. Scott has also appeared in the [[Comedy Central]] television show ''[[Nick Swardson's Pretend Time]]'', as a newscaster in the episode "Relapse into Refreshment". He has appeared in a series of commercials for [[ESPN]]'s Sunday Night Baseball. In November 2016, Scott guest starred in ''[[The Good Place]]'' season 1 as Trevor. In 2017, Scott appeared in HBO's ''[[Big Little Lies (TV series)|Big Little Lies]]''. Scott co-starred with [[Craig Robinson (actor)|Craig Robinson]] in the sitcom ''[[Ghosted (TV series)|Ghosted]]'',{{Cite news|url=http://deadline.com/2017/05/ghosted-la-to-vegas-comedies-fox-series-orders-1202088876/|title=‘Ghosted’ & ‘LA To Vegas’ Comedy Pilots Get Fox Series Orders|last=Andreeva|first=Nellie|date=2017-05-10|work=Deadline|access-date=2017-07-29|language=en-US}} which premiered on October 1, 2017 on [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]].{{Cite news|url=http://deadline.com/2017/06/fox-fall-2017-premiere-dates-empire-marvel-the-gifted-seth-macfarlane-orville-1202118456/|title=Fox Sets Fall 2017 Premiere Dates: ‘Empire’, New Marvel Drama ‘The Gifted’, Seth MacFarlane’s ‘Orville’ & More|last=Andreeva|first=Nellie|date=2017-06-22|work=Deadline|access-date=2017-07-29|language=en-US}} === Podcasting === With [[Scott Aukerman]], Scott is the co-host and co-creator of the [[Earwolf]] [[podcast]] ''U Talkin' U2 To Me'', launched in February 2014.{{cite web|url=http://www.earwolf.com/show/u-talkin-u2-to-me/|title=U Talkin' U2 To Me?|work=earwolf.com|accessdate=14 February 2015}} The series is introduced at the outset of each episode as "the comprehensive and encyclopedic compendium of all things [[U2]]," but it generally uses discussion of the band as a jumping off point for improv and absurdist humor. In February 2018 Scott and Scott launched another podcast in the same format, this time covering the career and work of the band [[R.E.M.]], titled ''R U Talkin’ R.E.M. Re: Me?''. Scott has also been a guest on numerous podcasts, including ''[[Comedy Bang! Bang!]]'', ''[[How Did This Get Made?]]'', and ''[[Kevin Pollak's Chat Show]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.earwolf.com/person/adam-scott/|title=Adam Scott|work=earwolf.com|accessdate=14 February 2015}} == Personal life == Adam Scott married Naomi Sablan in 2005. They have two children.{{Cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1133158/bio|title=Naomi Scott|website=IMDb|access-date=2017-05-15}} Scott revealed he invited actor [[Mark Hamill]] ([[Luke Skywalker]] from the ''[[Star Wars]]'' franchise) to his second grade birthday during his ''[[Jimmy Kimmel Live!]]'' appearance on May 4, 2017. Guest host [[Kristen Bell]] surprised Scott with the guest appearance of Hamill wielding a lightsaber in observance of [[Star Wars Day]].{{Cite news|url=https://people-com.cdn.ampproject.org/v/people.com/movies/adam-scott-star-wars-mark-hamill-surprise/amp/?amp_js_v=0.1|title=Watch Star Wars Super Fan Adam Scott’s Childhood Dreams Come True with a Surprise from Mark Hamill|work=PEOPLE.com|access-date=2017-05-15|language=en-US}} == Filmography == === Film === {| class="wikitable sortable" |- !
